description: This course introduces the basic concepts in kinematics and dynamics that are necessary to understand, analyze and design mechanisms and machines. These concepts are also fundamental to the modeling and analysis of human movement, biomechanics, animation of synthetic human models and robotics. The topics covered include: Particle dynamics using energy and momentum methods of analysis; Dynamics of systems of particles; Impact; Systems of variable mass; Kinematics and dynamics of rigid bodies in plane motion; Computer-aided dynamic simulation and animation.
name: ENG MECHANICS: DYNAMICS

values.comments:
This course introduces the basic concepts in kinematics and dynamics that are necessary to understand, analyze and design mechanisms and machines. These concepts are also fundamental to the modeling and analysis of human movement, biomechanics, animation of synthetic human models and robotics. The topics covered include: Particle dynamics using energy and momentum methods of analysis; Dynamics of systems of particles; Impact; Systems of variable mass; Kinematics and dynamics of rigid bodies in plane motion; Computer-aided dynamic simulation and animation.

Students overall reported this course to be \"fun and informative\", with the projects being an excellent way to reinforce studying material. However, many felt that the labs and the homework were not well related to the lectures, and the recitations didn\'t clarify the lectures or solve problem sets. Students found it hard to practice as neither the answers to the homework nor to the textbook problems were given. Students also felt that more emphasis was placed on real world applications rather than important theoretical knowledge.

This course was co-taught by Dr. Kumar, Dr. Fiene and Dr. Carchidi. Students in general thought concepts were well communicated, but a few said multiple professors made some lectures hard to follow. Dr. Kumar was \"stimulating in the classroom and very open to questions,\" and was able to \"present material quickly and interestingly\".

This course was designed as a sophomore level class, with prerequisite MEAM 210 and corequisite MATH 241. Students reported that few partial credits were given when homework and exams were graded. Due to its highly conflicting schedule with MEAM 247, students faced overwhelming workload sometime.
